summary: Email correspondence between a Senior Forensic Examiner (NY CART Coordinator) and an Assistant U.S. Attorney regarding the organization and transfer of digital evidence from search warrants executed on Jeffrey Epstein's properties. The emails discuss the status of data extraction from devices seized from Epstein's Manhattan apartment and his private island, coordination for a meeting, and the need for a detailed inventory spreadsheet.

persons.name: NY CART Coordinator Senior Forensic Examiner
persons.context: The primary correspondent providing technical details about the digital evidence seized from Epstein's properties, including the status of processing hard drives, Windows machines, Macs, and loose media.

persons.name: Assistant U.S. Attorney
persons.context: The recipient of the emails, seeking clarification and organization of the seized digital evidence for the case, requesting a meeting and a detailed spreadsheet inventory.

connections.person1: NY CART Coordinator Senior Forensic Examiner
connections.description: Correspondence regarding the coordination and transfer of digital evidence from the Epstein investigation, with the examiner providing technical updates and the attorney requesting organizational clarity.

events.title: Search of Epstein Property
events.description: A search was conducted on one of Jeffrey Epstein's properties, resulting in the seizure of hard drives.

events.title: Evidence Transfer Coordination
events.description: Email discussion about the need for an in-person meeting and a detailed spreadsheet to track all seized devices from Epstein's New York and Virgin Islands properties.
personsInvolved: NY CART Coordinator Senior Forensic Examiner

events.title: Meeting Scheduling
events.description: Proposal to schedule a meeting for Thursday morning to discuss the accounting of seized digital evidence.
personsInvolved: NY CART Coordinator Senior Forensic Examiner

locations: Island (Virgin Islands, likely referring to Epstein's private island)
keyFacts: Nine IDE hard drives were found in Epstein's Manhattan apartment, which were determined to be three copies of three drives from a July 2007 search of one of his properties.
Digital evidence seized included devices from both a New York mansion (approximately 40+ storage devices and 60+ CDs) and from the Virgin Islands (more than 25 devices, including multiple servers).
The forensic examiner had processed and transferred all Windows machines and loose media from the New York apartment, but some Apple/Mac items from New York and the Island remained to be produced.
The correspondence highlights significant organizational challenges in managing over a million documents from the seized evidence, necessitating a detailed tracking spreadsheet.
The emails are subject to a protective order covering specific paragraphs, indicating the sensitive nature of the evidence and investigation details.
